Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: I WENT down yesterday to the Piraeus with Glaucon the son of Ariston, that I might offer up my prayers to the goddess; and also because I wanted to see in what manner they would celebrate the festival, which was a new thing. I was delighted with the procession of the inhabitants; but that of the Thracians was equally, if not more, beautiful.  When we had finished our prayers and viewed the spectacle, we turned in the direction of the city; and at that instant Polemarchus the son of Cephalus chanced to catch sight of us from a distance as we were starting on our way home, and told his servant to run and bid us wait for him.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: I turned round, and asked him where his master was.

Speaker: SERVANT
Text: There he is, said the youth, coming after you, if you will only wait.

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: I perceive, Socrates, that you and our companion are already on your way to the city.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: You are not far wrong, I said.

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: But do you see, he rejoined, how many we are?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: And are you stronger than all these? for if not, you will have to remain where you are.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: May there not be the alternative, I said, that we may persuade you to let us go?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: But can you persuade us, if we refuse to listen to you? he said.

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Then we are not going to listen; of that you may be assured.

Speaker: ADEIMANTUS
Text: Has no one told you of the torch-race on horseback in honour of the goddess which will take place in the evening?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: With horses! That is a novelty. Will horsemen carry torches and pass them one to another during the race?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Yes, and not only so, but a festival will he celebrated at night, which you certainly ought to see.  Let us rise soon after supper and see this festival; there will be a gathering of young men, and we will have a good talk.  Stay then, and do not be perverse.

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: I suppose, since you insist, that we must.
